name: Szemerédi's theorem
rephrased: If a subset of the integers has positive density, then it contains arithmetic progressions of arbitrary length.
implication_form: If a subset of the integers has positive natural density, then it contains a k-term arithmetic progression for every k.
explained: Szemerédi's theorem states that any subset of the integers with positive upper density contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. In other words, if a subset A of the integers has positive density (a concept rigorously defined in additive combinatorics), then for any integer k, A contains a k-term arithmetic progression.
